page.title: 20ALMONDBANK-TEXTILE INDUSTRY
page.content: The second area offers a distinct difference from the first. In many ways it offers a goldmine of information and evidence to the student of industrial archaeology. The broad but gently flowing River Almond provided the source of power and water supply necessary to develop a successful textile industry. A local told us how, in the not too distant past, the mills provided work for most of the local inhabitants, both male and female. The entire process of the production of linen to dying and distribution was carried on in the various factory units. Today, all that remains is the derelict shell of the Pitcairnfield works, the tram tines for moving batches of cloth to the dying works and several lades, weirs and water wheels.
